Name: The Shepherd
Line1: How sweet is the Shepherd's sweet lot!
Line2: From the morn to the evening he stays;
Line3: He shall follow his sheep all the day,
Line4: And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
Line5: For he hears the lambs' innocent call,
Line6: And he hears the ewes' tender reply;
Line7: He is watching while they are in peace,
Line8: For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

Name: The Echoing Green
Line1: The sun does arise,
Line2: And make happy the skies;
Line3: The merry bells ring
Line4: To welcome the Spring;
Line5: The skylark and thrush,
Line6: The birds of the bush,
Line7: Sing louder around
Line8: To the bells' cheerful sound;
Line9: While our sports shall be seen
Line10: On the echoing Green.
Line11: Old John, with white hair,
Line12: Does laugh away care,
Line13: Sitting under the oak,
Line14: Among the old folk.
Line15: They laugh at our play,
Line17: "Such, such were the joys
Line18: When we all--girls and boys--
Line19: In our youth-time were seen
Line20: On the echoing Green."
Line21: Till the little ones, weary,
Line22: No more can be merry:
Line23: The sun does descend,
Line24: And our sports have an end.
Line25: Round the laps of their mothers

Name: The Lamb
Line1: Little Lamb, who made thee
Line2: Dost thou know who made thee,
Line3: Gave thee life, and bid thee feed
Line4: By the stream and o'er the mead;
Line5: Gave thee clothing of delight,
Line6: Softest clothing, woolly, bright;
Line7: Gave thee such a tender voice,
Line8: Making all the vales rejoice?
Line9: Little Lamb, who made thee?
Line10: Dost thou know who made thee?
Line11: Little Lamb, I'll tell thee;
Line12: Little Lamb, I'll tell thee:
Line13: He is called by thy name,
Line14: For He calls Himself a Lamb
Line15: He is meek, and He is mild,
Line17: I a child, and thou a lamb,
Line18: We are called by His name.
Line19: Little Lamb, God bless thee!
Line20: Little Lamb, God bless thee!

Name: The Little Black Boy
Line1: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
Line2: And Iam black, but oh my soul is white!
Line3: White as an angel is the English child,
Line4: But I am black, as if bereaved of light.
Line5: My mother taught me underneath a tree,
Line6: And, sitting down before the heat of day,
Line7: She took me on her lap and kissed me,
Line8: And, pointed to the east, began to say:
Line9: "Look on the rising sun: there God does live,
Line10: And gives His light, and gives His heat away,
Line11: And flowers and trees and beasts and men receive
Line12: Comfort in morning, joy in the noonday.
Line13: "And we are put on earth a little space,
Line14: That we may learn to bear the beams of love
Line15: And these black bodies and this sunburnt face
Line16: Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.
Line17: "For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear,
Line18: The cloud will vanish, we shall hear His voice,
Line19: Saying, 'Come out from the grove, my love and care
Line20: And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice',"
Line21: Thus did my mother say, and kissed me;
Line22: And thus I say to little English boy.
Line23: When I from black and he from white cloud free,
Line24: And round the tent of God like lambs we joy
Line25: I'll shade him from the heat till he can bear
Line26: To lean in joy upon our Father's knee;
Line27: And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair,
Line28: And be like him, and he will then love me.

Name: The Blossom
Line1: Merry, merry sparrow!
Line2: Under leaves so green
Line3: A happy blossom
Line4: Sees you, swift as arrow,
Line5: Seek your cradle narrow,
Line6: Near my bosom.
Line7: Pretty, pretty robin!
Line8: Under leaves so green
Line9: A happy blossom
Line10: Hears you sobbing, sobbing,
Line11: Pretty, pretty robin,
Line12: Near my bosom.

Name: The Chimney Sweeper
Line1: When my mother died I was very young,
Line2: And my father sold me while yet my tongue
Line3: Could scarcely cry "Weep! weep! weep! weep!"
Line4: So your chimneys I sweep, and in soot I sleep.
Line5: There's little Tom Dacre, who cried when his head,
Line6: That curled like a lamb's back, was shaved; so I said,
Line7: "Hush, Tom! never mind it, for, when your head's bare,
Line8: You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair."
Line9: And so he was quiet, and that very night,
Line10: As Tom was a-sleeping, he had such a sight!--
Line11: That thousands of sweepers, Dick, Joe, Ned, and Jack,
Line12: Were all of them locked up in coffins of black.
Line13: And by came an angel, who had a bright key,
Line14: And he opened the coffins, and let them all free;
Line15: Then down a green plain, leaping, laughing, they run,
Line16: And wash in a river, and shine in the sun.
Line17: Then naked and white, all their bags left behind,
Line18: They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind;
Line19: And the Angel told Tom, if he'd be a good boy,
Line20: He'd have God for his father, and never want joy.
Line21: And so Tom awoke, and we rose in the dark,
Line22: And got with our bags and our brushes to work.
Line23: Though the morning was cold, Tom was happy and warm:
Line24: So, if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

Name: The Little Boy Lost
Line1: "Father, father, where are you going?
Line2: Oh do not walk so fast!
Line3: Speak, father, speak to your little boy,
Line4: Or else I shall be lost."
Line5: The night was dark, no father was there,
Line6: The child was wet with dew;
Line7: The mire was deep, and the child did weep,
Line8: And away the vapour flew.

Name: The Little Boy Found
Line1: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Line2: Led by the wandering light,
Line3: Began to cry, but God, ever nigh,
Line4: Appeared like his father, in white.
Line5: He kissed the child, and by the hand led,
Line6: And to his mother brought,
Line7: Who in sorrow pale, through the lonely dale,
Line8: The little boy weeping sought.

Name: Laughing Song
Line1: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy,
Line2: And the dimpling stream runs laughing by;
Line3: When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
Line4: And the green hill laughs with the noise of it;
Line5: when the meadows laugh with lively green,
Line6: And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
Line7: When Mary and Susan and Emily
Line8: With their sweet round mouths sing "Ha, ha he!"
Line9: When the painted birds laugh in the shade,
Line10: Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread:
Line11: Come live, and be merry, and join with me,
Line12: To sing the sweet chorus of "Ha, ha, he!"

Name: Asong
Line1: Sweet dreams, form a shade
Line2: O'er my lovely infant's head!
Line3: Sweet dreams of pleasant streams
Line4: By happy, silent, moony beams!
Line5: Sweet Sleep, with soft down
Line6: Weave thy brows an infant crown
Line7: Sweet Sleep, angel mild,
Line8: Hover o'er my happy child!
Line9: Sweet smiles, in the night
Line10: Hover over my delight!
Line11: Sweet smiles, mother's smile,
Line12: All the livelong night beguile.
Line13: Sweet moans, dovelike sighs,
Line14: Chase not slumber from thine eyes!
Line15: Sweet moan, sweeter smile,
Line17: Sleep, sleep, happy child!
Line18: All creation slept and smiled.
Line19: Sleep, sleep, happy sleep,
Line20: While o'er thee doth mother weep.
Line21: Sweet babe, in thy face
Line22: Holy image I can trace;
Line23: Sweet babe, once like thee
Line24: Thy Maker lay, and wept for me:
Line25: Wept for me, for thee, for all,
Line26: When He was an infant small.
Line28: Heavenly face that smiles on thee!
Line29: Smiles on thee, on me, on all,
Line31: Infant smiles are his own smiles;
Line32: Heaven and earth to peace beguiles.

Name: Divine Image
Line1: To Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line2: All pray in their distress,
Line3: And to these virtues of delight
Line4: Return their thankfulness.
Line5: For Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line6: Is God our Father dear;
Line7: And Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line8: Is man, his child and care.
Line9: For Mercy has a human heart
Line10: Pity, a human face;
Line11: And Love, the human form divine;
Line12: And Peace, the human dress.
Line13: Then every man, of every clime,
Line14: That prays in his distress,
Line15: Prays to the human form divine:
Line17: And all must love the human form,
Line18: In heathen, Turk, or Jew.
Line19: Where Mercy, Love, and Pity dwell,
Line20: There God is dwelling too.

Name: Holy Thursday
Line1: 'Twas on a Holy Thursday, their innocent faces clean,
Line2: Came children walking two and two, in read, and blue, and green:
Line3: Grey-headed beadles walked before, with wands as white as snow,
Line4: Till into the high dome of Paul's they like Thames waters flow.
Line5: Oh what a multitude they seemed, these flowers of London town!
Line6: Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own.
Line7: The hum of multitudes was there, but multitudes of lambs,
Line8: Thousands of little boys and girls raising their innocent hands.
Line9: Now like a mighty wild they raise to heaven the voice of song,
Line10: Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among:
Line11: Beneath them sit the aged man, wise guardians of the poor.
Line12: Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door.

Name: Night
Line1: The sun descending in the west,
Line2: The evening star does shine;
Line3: The birds are silent in their nest,
Line4: And I must seek for mine.
Line5: The moon, like a flower
Line6: In heaven's high bower,
Line7: With silent delight,
Line8: Sits and smiles on the night.
Line9: Farewell, green fields and happy grove,
Line10: Where flocks have ta'en delight.
Line11: Where lambs have nibbled, silent move
Line12: The feet of angels bright;
Line13: Unseen they pour blessing,
Line14: And joy without ceasing,
Line15: On each bud and blossom,
Line17: They look in every thoughtless nest
Line18: Where birds are covered warm;
Line19: They visit caves of every beast,
Line20: To keep them all from harm:
Line21: If they see any weeping
Line22: That should have been sleeping,
Line23: They pour sleep on their head,
Line24: And sit down by their bed.
Line25: When wolves and tigers howl for prey,
Line27: Seeking to drive their thirst away,
Line28: And keep them from the sheep.
Line33: And there the lion's ruddy eyes
Line34: Shall flow with tears of gold:
Line42: I can lie down and sleep,
Line43: Or think on Him who bore thy name,
Line48: As I guard o'er the fold."

Name: Spring
Line1: Sound the flute!
Line2: Now it's mute!
Line3: Bird's delight,
Line4: Day and night,
Line5: Nightingale,
Line6: In the dale,
Line7: Lark in sky,--
Line8: Merrily,
Line9: Merrily merrily, to welcome in the year.
Line10: Little boy,
Line11: Full of joy;
Line12: Little girl,
Line13: Sweet and small;
Line14: Cock does crow,
Line15: So do you;
Line17: Infant noise;
Line18: Merrily, merrily, to welcome in the year.
Line19: Little lamb,
Line20: Here I am;
Line21: Come and lick
Line22: My white neck;
Line23: Let me pull
Line24: Your soft wool;
Line27: Merrily, merrily, to welcome in the year.

Name: Nurse's Song
Line1: When the voices of children are heard on the green,
Line2: And laughing is heard on the hill,
Line3: My heart is at rest within my breast,
Line4: And everything else is still.
Line5: "Then come home, my children, the sun is gone down,
Line6: And the dews of night arise;
Line7: Come, come, leave off play, and let us away,
Line8: Till the morning appears in the skies."
Line9: "No, no, let us play, for it is yet day,
Line10: And we cannot go to sleep;
Line11: Besides, in the sky the little birds fly,
Line12: And the hills are all covered with sheep."
Line13: "Well, well, go and play till the light fades away,
Line14: And then go home to bed."
Line15: The little ones leaped, and shouted, and laughed,

Name: Infant Joy
Line1: "I have no name;
Line2: I am but two days old."
Line3: What shall I call thee?
Line4: "I happy am,
Line5: Joy is my name."
Line6: Sweet joy befall thee!
Line7: Pretty joy!
Line8: Sweet joy, but two days old.
Line9: Sweet Joy I call thee:
Line10: Thou dost smile,
Line11: I sing the while;
Line12: Sweet joy befall thee!

Name: A Dream
Line1: Once a dream did weave a shade
Line2: O'er my angel-guarded bed,
Line3: That an emmet lost its way
Line4: Where on grass methought I lay.
Line5: Troubled, wildered, and forlorn,
Line6: Dark, benighted, travel-worn,
Line7: Over many a tangle spray,
Line8: All heart-broke, I heard her say:
Line9: "Oh my children! do they cry,
Line10: Do they hear their father sigh?
Line11: Now they look abroad to see,
Line12: Now return and weep for me."
Line13: Pitying, I dropped a tear:
Line14: But I saw a glow-worm near,
Line15: Who replied, "What wailing wight
Line16: Calls the watchman of the night?
Line17: "I am set to light the ground,
Line18: While the beetle goes his round:
Line19: Follow now the beetle's hum;
Line20: Little wanderer, hie thee home!"

Name: On Another's Sorrow
Line1: Can I see another's woe,
Line2: And not be in sorrow too?
Line3: Can I see another's grief,
Line4: And not seek for kind relief?
Line5: Can I see a falling tear,
Line6: And not feel my sorrow's share?
Line7: Can a father see his child
Line8: Weep, nor be with sorrow filled?
Line9: Can a mother sit and hear
Line10: An infant groan, an infant fear?
Line11: No, no!never can it be!
Line12: Never, never can it be!
Line13: And can He who smiles on all
Line14: Hear the wren with sorrows small,
Line15: Hear the small bird's grief and care,
Line16: Hear the woes that infants bear--
Line17: And not sit beside the next,
Line18: Pouring pity in their breast,
Line19: And not sit the cradle near,
Line20: Weeping tear on infant's tear?
Line21: And not sit both night and day,
Line22: Wiping all our tears away?
Line23: Oh no! never can it be!
Line24: Never, never can it be!
Line25: He doth give his joy to all:
Line27: He becomes a man of woe,
Line28: He doth feel the sorrow too.
Line29: Think not thou canst sigh a sigh,
Line30: And thy Maker is not by:
Line31: Think not thou canst weep a tear,
Line32: And thy Maker is not near.
Line33: Oh He gives to us his joy,
Line34: That our grief He may destroy:
Line35: Till our grief is fled an gone
Line36: He doth sit by us and moan.

Name: Introduction to Songs of Experience
Line1: Hear the voice of the Bard,
Line2: Who present, past, and future, sees;
Line3: Whose ears have heard
Line4: The Holy Word
Line5: That walked among the ancient tree;
Line6: Calling the lapsed soul,
Line7: And weeping in the evening dew;
Line8: That might control
Line9: The starry pole,
Line10: And fallen, fallen light renew!
Line11: "O Earth, O Earth, return!
Line12: Arise from out the dewy grass!
Line13: Night is worn,
Line14: And the morn
Line15: Rises from the slumbrous mass.
Line17: Why wilt thou turn away?
Line18: The starry floor,
Line19: The watery shore,
Line20: Are given thee till the break of day."

Name: Earth's Answer
Line1: Earth raised up her head
Line2: From the darkness dread and drear,
Line3: Her light fled,
Line4: Stony, dread,
Line5: And her locks covered with grey despair.
Line6: "Prisoned on watery shore,
Line7: Starry jealousy does keep my den
Line8: Cold and hoar;
Line9: Weeping o'er,
Line10: I hear the father of the ancient men.
Line11: "Selfish father of men!
Line12: Cruel, jealous, selfish fear!
Line13: Can delight,
Line14: Chained in night,
Line15: The virgins of youth and morning bear?
Line17: When buds and blossoms grow?
Line18: Does the sower
Line19: Sow by night,
Line20: Or the plowman in darkness plough?
Line21: "Break this heavy chain,
Line22: That does freeze my bones around!
Line23: Selfish, vain,
Line24: Eternal bane,
Line25: That free love with bondage bound."

Name: The Clod and the Pebble
Line1: "Love seeketh not itself to please,
Line2: Nor for itself hath any care,
Line3: But for another gives it ease,
Line4: And builds a heaven in hell's despair."
Line5: So sang a little clod of clay,
Line6: Trodden with the cattle's feet,
Line7: But a pebble of the brook
Line8: Warbled out these metres meet:
Line9: "Love seeketh only Self to please,
Line10: To bind another to its delight,
Line11: Joys in another's loss of ease,
Line12: And builds a hell in heaven's despite."

Name: Holy Thursday
Line1: Is this a holy thing to see
Line2: In a rich and fruitful land,--
Line3: Babes reduced to misery,
Line4: Fed with cold and usurous hand?
Line5: Is that trembling cry a song?
Line6: Can it be a song of joy?
Line7: And so many children poor?
Line8: It is a land of poverty!
Line9: And their son does never shine,
Line10: And their fields are bleak and bare,
Line11: And their ways are filled with thorns:
Line12: It is eternal winter there.
Line13: For where'er the sun does shine,
Line14: And where'er the rain does fall,
Line15: Babes should never hunger there,

Name: The Little Girl Lost
Line1: In futurity
Line2: I prophetic see
Line3: That the earth from sleep
Line4: (Grave the sentence deep)
Line5: Shall arise, and seek
Line6: for her Maker meek;
Line7: And the desert wild
Line8: Become a garden mild.
Line9: In the southern clime,
Line10: Where the summer's prime
Line11: Never fades away,
Line12: Lovely Lyca lay.
Line13: Seven summers old
Line14: Lovely Lyca told.
Line15: She had wandered long,
Line17: "Sweet sleep, come to me
Line18: Underneath this tree;
Line19: Do father, mother, weep?
Line20: Where can Lyca sleep?
Line21: "Lost in desert wild
Line22: Is your little child.
Line23: How can Lyca sleep
Line24: If her mother weep?

Name: The Little Girl Found
Line1: All the night in woe
Line2: Lyca's parents go
Line3: Over valleys deep,
Line4: While the deserts weep.
Line5: Tired and woe-begone,
Line6: Hoarse with making moan,
Line7: Arm in arm, seven days
Line8: They traced the desert ways.
Line9: Seven nights they sleep
Line10: Among shadows deep,
Line11: And dream they see their child
Line12: Starved in desert wild.
Line13: Pale through pathless ways
Line14: The fancied image strays,
Line15: Famished, weeping, weak,
Line17: Rising from unrest,
Line18: The trembling woman pressed
Line19: With feet of weary woe;
Line20: She could no further go.
Line21: In his arms he bore
Line22: Her, armed with sorrow sore;
Line23: Till before their way
Line24: A couching lion lay.

Name: The Chimney Sweeper
Line1: A little black thing in the snow,
Line2: Crying "weep! weep!" in notes of woe!
Line3: "Where are thy father and mother? Say!"--
Line4: "They are both gone up to the church to pray.
Line5: "Because I was happy upon the heath,
Line6: And smiled among the winter's snow,
Line7: They clothed me in the clothes of death,
Line8: And taught me to sing the notes of woe.
Line9: "And because I am happy and dance and sing,
Line10: They think they have done me no injury,
Line11: And are gone to praise God and his priest and king,
Line12: Who make up a heaven of our misery."

Name: Nurse's Song II
Line1: When voices of children are heard on the green,
Line2: And whisperings are in the dale,
Line3: The days of my youth rise fresh in my mind,
Line4: My face turns green and pale.
Line5: Then come home, my children, the sun is gone down,
Line6: And the dews of night arise;
Line7: Your spring and your day are wasted in play,
Line8: And your winter and night in disguise.

Name: The Sick Rose
Line1: O rose, thou art sick!
Line2: The invisible worm,
Line3: That flies in the night,
Line4: In the howling storm,
Line5: Has found out thy bed
Line6: Of crimson joy,
Line7: And his dark secret love
Line8: Does thy life destroy.

Name: The Fly
Line1: Little Fly,
Line2: Thy summer's play
Line3: My thoughtless hand
Line4: Has brushed away.
Line5: Am not I
Line6: A fly like thee?
Line7: Or art not thou
Line8: A man like me?
Line9: For I dance
Line10: And drink, and sing,
Line11: Till some blind hand
Line12: Shall brush my wing.
Line13: If thought is life
Line14: And strength and breath
Line15: And the want
Line17: Then am I
Line18: A happy fly,
Line19: If I live,
Line20: Or if I die.

Name: The Angel
Line1: I dreamt a dream!What can it mean?
Line2: And that I was a maiden Queen
Line3: Guarded by an Angel mild:
Line4: Witless woe was ne'er beguiled!
Line5: And I wept both night and day,
Line6: And he wiped my tears away;
Line7: And I wept both day and night,
Line8: And hid from him my heart's delight.
Line9: So he took his wings, and fled;
Line10: Then the morn blushed rosy red.
Line11: I dried my tears, and armed my fears
Line12: With ten-thousand shields and spears.
Line13: Soon my Angel came again;
Line14: I was armed, he came in vain;
Line15: For the time of youth was fled,
Line16: And grey hairs were on my head.

Name: The Tyger
Line1: Tyger, tyger, burning bright
Line2: In the forests of the night,
Line3: What immortal hand or eye
Line4: Could frame thy fearful symmetry?
Line5: In what distant deeps or skies
Line6: Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
Line7: On what wings dare he aspire?
Line8: What the hand dare seize the fire?
Line9: And what shoulder and what art
Line10: Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
Line11: And, when thy heart began to beat,
Line12: What dread hand and what dread feet?
Line13: What the hammer?what the chain?
Line14: In what furnace was thy brain?
Line15: What the anvil? what dread grasp
Line17: When the stars threw down their spears,
Line18: And watered heaven with their tears,
Line19: Did he smile his work to see?
Line20: Did he who made the lamb make thee?
Line21: Tyger, tyger, burning bright
Line22: In the forests of the night,
Line23: What immortal hand or eye
Line24: Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?

Name: My Pretty Rose Tree
Line1: A flower was offered to me,
Line2: Such a flower as May never bore;
Line3: But I said "I've a pretty rose tree,"
Line4: And I passed the sweet flower o'er.
Line5: Then I went to my pretty rose tree,
Line6: To tend her by day and by night;
Line7: But my rose turned away with jealousy,
Line8: And her thorns were my only delight.

Name: Sunflower
Line1: Ah Sunflower, weary of time,
Line2: Who countest the steps of the sun;
Line3: Seeking after that sweet golden clime
Line4: Where the traveller's journey is done;
Line5: Where the Youth pined away with desire,
Line6: And the pale virgin shrouded in snow,
Line7: Arise from their graves, and aspire
Line8: Where my Sunflower wishes to go!

Name: The Lilly
Line1: The modest Rose puts forth a thorn,
Line2: The humble sheep a threat'ning horn:
Line3: While the Lily white shall in love delight,
Line4: Nor a thorn nor a threat stain her beauty bright.

Name: Garden of Love
Line1: I laid me down upon a bank,
Line2: Where Love lay sleeping;
Line3: I heard among the rushes dank
Line4: Weeping, weeping.
Line5: Then I went to the heath and the wild,
Line6: To the thistles and thorns of the waste;
Line7: And they told me how they were beguiled,
Line8: Driven out, and compelled to the chaste.
Line9: I went to the Garden of Love,
Line10: And saw what I never had seen;
Line11: A Chapel was built in the midst,
Line12: Where I used to play on the green.
Line13: And the gates of this Chapel were shut
Line14: And "Thou shalt not," writ over the door;
Line15: So I turned to the Garden of Love
Line16: That so many sweet flowers bore.
Line17: And I saw it was filled with graves,
Line18: And tombstones where flowers should be;
Line19: And priests in black gowns were walking their rounds,
Line20: And binding with briars my joys and desires.

Name: The Little Vagabond
Line1: Dear mother, dear mother, the Church is cold;
Line2: But the Alehouse is healthy, and pleasant, and warm.
Line3: Besides, I can tell where I am used well;
Line4: The poor parsons with wind like a blown bladder swell.
Line5: But, if at the Church they would give us some ale,
Line6: And a pleasant fire our souls to regale,
Line7: We'd sing and we'd pray all the livelong day,
Line8: Nor ever once wish from the Church to stray.
Line9: Then the Parson might preach, and drink, and sing,
Line10: And we'd be as happy as birds in the spring;
Line11: And modest Dame Lurch, who is always at church,
Line12: Would not have bandy children, nor fasting, nor birch.
Line13: And God, like a father, rejoicing to see
Line14: His children as pleasant and happy as he,
Line15: Would have no more quarrel with the Devil or the barrel,
Line16: But kiss him, and give him both drink and apparel.

Name: London
Line1: I wandered through each chartered street,
Line2: Near where the chartered Thames does flow,
Line3: A mark in every face I meet,
Line4: Marks of weakness, marks of woe.
Line5: In every cry of every man,
Line6: In every infant's cry of fear,
Line7: In every voice, in every ban,
Line8: The mind-forged manacles I hear:
Line9: How the chimney-sweeper's cry
